top_comment.text:
How would this work if you're introducing two cats, in a new home? Say I'm 
moving into an apartment with a friend of mine, he's bringing his cat, and 
I'm bringing mine. Neither cat would have a home field advantage, which may 
be good, but would strategy be different?﻿
top_comment.author: Tori Cook

comments.text:
Please let me know how this went. I am going to be going through the same 
thing!
comments.author: MaxluvsMya

comments.text:
No, the strategy would not be different.  But, since each cat will not only 
be getting used to a stranger cat, they will be dealing with a strange 
environment, and another person they are not used to living with.  That is 
a LOT for a cat to deal with.  So be sure to go extra slow with things.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

top_comment.text: Hey Jackson please answer do I free feed a a kitten growing up﻿
top_comment.author: William Zajicek

comments.text:
I always free fed kittens some dry food, but then also did scheduled wet 
food meals.  Young kittens grow so fast and need to eat a lot, so I like to 
make sure they don't go hungry during that very rapid growth stage.  By 
around 7 months, their growth slows down, and their stomachs can hold more 
at one time, so by then they can do fine with set meal times. They are 
still growing, though, so make sure to serve at least three meals a day, 
and maybe leave some dry food out for overnight.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
I think free feeding is feeding them whenever their bowl is empty, rather 
than on a timed schedule. That way they always have food in their bowl and 
can eat whenever they feel like, rather than, only when you say they can.
comments.author: Cssndr Mks

top_comment.text:
My husband wants to get another cat, a kitten... We already have 1female 
and 1male. The female is 7yrs old, shes a bit sassy and male 2yrs old he 
plays rough. It worries me to get a kitten with these two polar opposites 
in one household. Its still undecided if we are getting a F or M but as 
along as its fixed we will adopt on the spot. Of course i will keep the 
kitten in our room when we are both at work and on my days off i would try 
this out and introduce them to one another. I just wanted to know if 
someone has done this before, introducing a older cat or a younger one? 
Does gender play a major role? ﻿
top_comment.author: omo ottoke

comments.text:
Gender does not exist in neutered cats. They are neutral.  Boys can have 
boy buddies, girls can be friends, and mixed pairs can be peaceful.   
Adding a kitten to a household with older cats is more problematic than 
looking for a cat within your current age range.  It sounds like you need a 
feline-assertive to stand up to the boy, so look for a kitty willing to 
wrestle with other cats.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
Gender seems to play a role but energy levels are most important. If I were 
you I would try to match the energy level of the 2 year old so your female 
can have more time to relax. My roommate has a cat, sophie, she is 5 years 
old. I have two cats and they were 6 months at the time (both male, 
brothers). It took a while but eventually they got along fine, sometimes on 
of the boys pushes sophie's buttons but overall everyone gets along.
comments.author: datplaylist10

top_comment.text:
10 years ago, we moved in to our new house. NObody had territory. They 
seemed to get along for about two weeks. Then we realized that the old lady 
was cornering one of the other kitties and keeping her from food and the 
box. We tried all of things for months, including a behaviorist. Old lady 
is just hyper focused and a jerk. Spatter is just afraid of up stairs if 
the bedroom door is open. They are all so old, I just wonder if its worth 
it to try again.﻿
top_comment.author: Diane S

comments.text:
FYI, We have two. One Cat genie (yes, I know Jackson doesnt like them but I 
am having no trouble monitoring frequency and types of poo n pee) belongs 
to Old lady and one belongs to the other two (with two washing cycles per 
day). This set up has been for at least 6 or 7 years now.
comments.author: Diane S

comments.text:
To help with the box, have several boxes.  Grumpy Old Lady can only guard 
one. You can also feed in separate areas until you go through the process.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

Well...when I brought our little Lola home years ago and she was 6 
weeks...her 2plus year old sister and her hit it off within a month and

comments.author: Pamela Tracy

comments.text:
+Niko Combitsis   Keep the cats in separate rooms.  It does not make sense 
to stress them out by forcing them together if the co-habitation is less 
than month.  The stress is then doubled back when they are separated so the 
cats are more likely to get sick as a result.  Petsitting by visiting the 
cat in its home turf is ALWAYS better for the cat, as they are territorial 
creatures.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
I'm cat sitting my friend's cat for about 4-6 weeks, and my resident cat 
does NOT like this new cat. What do I do with such a small amount of time?? 
(I live in a rather small place)
comments.author: Niko Combitsis

comments.text: https://m.facebook.com/MrPursemusFeline
comments.author: Meagan Lavender

comments.text:
Do you think some cats aren't meant to be with other cats? For example 
which sadly real life. My family had to watch a cat for a while it was a 
much older cat and smelt a bit odd later we found out after it went back to 
it home it died a month later. This cat hiss and would never come out and 
just in a bad mood. This sadly I think is the reason my cat associates all 
other cats as bad. Do you think she will ever be okay with other cats?
comments.author: Rebekkah Vickers

comments.text:
Maybe it should have been a female.  My cat accepted her little sister in 
about a month without any real problems.......she got very bonded with her 
little sister
comments.author: Pamela Tracy

comments.text:
Thanks for posting this!  We have a "Penny Hates Puck" situation.  Calico 
female who beats up, viciously, on our older, mild mannered male cat.  He's 
quite traumatized to even see her.  I don't know if they will ever get 
along.  She got at him, by my mistake of leaving a door opened the other 
day.  He is back to walking in a slow slink and hiding behind the bed, ever 
since.  I feel so badly about it!  We keep them separated for almost a year 
now, and have tried some of these techniques, but she seems to have a screw 
loose.  I am thinking she might always have to be kept separated from the 
two boys we have.   She also lunges viciously at our other male cat, who is 
the same age as her, but he doesn't seem to get as traumatized...but of 
course, we still keep them apart.  When they see each other under a door, 
they go at it with paws under the door.  The young male had to have 
antibiotics because she hurt his paw, last month, from under the door.  
Blocking the doors with towels doesn't work   She just pulls on them until 
they are on her side, and she could see under the door, again. 

We would re-home her to an only cat situation, but here in Florida, there 
are no no-kill shelters or fosters that have any free space, and people who 
are looking for cats have their choice of thousands since there are so many 
in shelters and rescues.  We don't have any other options, but to keep her 
here, and feel bad that she is so confined for most of the day.  She gets 
some free time out when boys are locked up, but it is limited.

She won't eat, at all, not even treats, if she knows that there is another 
cat on the other side of the door.  She is more obsessed with who is out 
there.  No distraction gets her away from obsessing with the door.  That is 
why I don't think the techniques in this video will work for the calico.
comments.author: FlourishingLight

comments.text:
My cats get along ok. They sometimes chase each other around the room and 
my male cat gets quite grumpy about it. One is very social (it seems to 
me), and my male is just grumpy solitary type. Had a neighboor cat visit at 
the door, and the female was all hi, sup? Lemme greet you with a bump in 
the face!" while my male is all hissing and nervous. Don't think I ever saw 
them fight for real. And hope I never will.
comments.author: mirawenya

top_comment.text:
Hi I'm have a New 3months old Persian but this is my first time that I have 
persisn inside my house. But the problem is, he poops 5times in 1day is 
that okay ? Or not? And How often bath the 3months old kitten? Is it, once 
or twice a week?﻿
top_comment.author: Laarni Dungca

comments.text:
+Laarni Dungca
( I'm thinking out loud here, so don't mind me ! ! ! ).

Persian kitties are known for their long fur. 

If you allow your precious feline friends outside, this could mean that his 
or her fur will get dirty, no doubt. 

With that said, giving your kitty a bath at least twice a month, should 
not be a problem. 

I had an aunt who had a Persian kitty named Lucy.  

Lucy was white and although my aunt allowed to roam outside, I don't think 
that Lucy's fur got dirty.  

My aunt STILL gave her a bath, anyways.   

Not everyday, just occasionally.  

Lucy was a spoiled kitty, as she would not jump up on the dining room table 
nor did she eat anything you offered her from the table. 

( If you had leftover food in your plate and you offered it to her, she 
would walk away from it ).  

She would only eat her cat food ! ! ! 

Sadly, Lucy got sick, ( her fur started to fall out ), and my aunt had to 
give her to the shelter.
comments.author: ms. will always love my life

comments.text:
Actually I Bought this kitten persian when he was 3mos. Then the owner of 
kitten or persian cat , she said that I will do twice a month to bath our 
kitten. Is that right?
comments.author: Laarni Dungca

comments.text:
+Laarni Dungca 
You should not have to bathe your precious kitty at all, as cats usually 
groom themselves.  

( I thought everyone knew this ).  

However, if kitties' fur is dirty or he / she may have fleas or ticks, then 
a bathe certainly would be needed.   

But as far as your kitty, um, " pooping " more than five times for the day, 
it could be 'cause of one of the following:

( 1 )   It could be that the cat food you are feeding him / her is not 
agreeing with his / her stomach

( 2 )   Your kitty is just getting used to his / her environment, which is 
probably causing him / her an upset stomach 

You could try a different brand of cat food or better yet, take your 
precious feline friend to the vet.    

Of course, the above statement was just my opinion.  

I am not a vet.
comments.author: ms. will always love my life

top_comment.text:

Any advice?﻿

comments.author: Jeanette Zimmer

top_comment.text:
Jackson, the two-cat dynamic going on in my home has a slight variation to 
the standard version you are addressing in vid. I have 2 neutered males, 
6-7 yrs. One of my cats (I'll call him Cat A) had to go to the vet recently 
(UT crystals, which I caught right away), and since keeping them separated 
while he recoups, the other one (Cat B) has become circumspect of him, and 
they can't seem to be reintroduced without a bloodbath! They were never 
lovey-dovey to begin with, but they, at least, had an acceptance of the 
other and have always spent most of their time in the same room hanging 
out... until now. Additionally, the day I had to take Cat A to the vet, my 
first attempt at getting him in the carrier was a colossal FAIL, and Cat B 
was so agitated by the commotion, hissing and protests of Cat A that he was 
compelled to beat the F--- out of Cat A! Energy escalating energy! Poor Cat 
A was already weakened by feeling sick, only to wind up getting blood and 
fur drawn! It was as if they had established some sort of new dynamic of 
searing hate towards each other, of which, I can't seem to reset!
Should I treat them like two strangers now - introducing them for the first 
time? Or, considering that they have known each other for years, is there 
another method or technique that would work more specifically? These cats 
live here year-round with my 80 yr old mother, while I am here only for the 
winter months. When I leave town, they will remain with her, and I can't 
afford to have her managing a nightmare at her age, by herself! Thank you 
so much, Jackson! Blessings to you always...
PS. I am also a musician - like you!﻿
top_comment.author: Donya Lane

comments.text:
+Kay Baggett Thank you for sharing and suggestions. I did work it out, 
mostly by doing EVERYTHING that Jackson explains in this video. The only 
variation was that I never used a gate. I used door stops and just started 
jamming the door opened by a few inches when they were eating. It took 
about a week of patience and being as inventive and creative as necessary. 
The point you made about your cat preventing the other from using the 
box... wow, that's horrible! I have not observed that going on here, but I 
will keep an eye out. I also added an extra box to the house, which helps.
comments.author: Donya Lane

comments.text:
+Donya Lane I think that B has probably been keeping A from the litter box 
and so he's holding his urine and that can cause crystals. Also B has 
probably been keeping A from the water bowl and that can cause crystals. I 
had the same issue and didn't realize it till my female cat had to have 
major surgery. If you can keep B shut up when getting A into the kennel and 
if you can keep B away from A to allow A to heal it will be good. There 
must be fresh water every day and in several places to help A get well and 
keep the crystals from coming back. Also cats sense when another is weak 
and sometimes they want to take advantage of that. So B is bullying A 
because A is sick. Feel badly for your mother.
comments.author: Kay Baggett

comments.text:
PS. I just realized that you probably answered my question already @ 5:52. 
Thank you for all these methods. I guess this means we are starting over 
from the very beginning in this house... Peace is the goal (for cats AND 
humans!).
comments.author: Donya Lane

top_comment.text:
Hi, great video. And what if you already have one cat and you are thinking 
of adopting a new one? Is it better to adopt a kitten or an adult?
For example I have a 2.5 year old female? Should I get a kitten to try and 
stimulate her motherly instincts? Would it be better to get a make our 
female kitten? Lastly, is it anthropomorphy to believe that it would be 
better for her to share her life with a male (they would be spayed and 
neutered of course)?﻿
top_comment.author: Photoandcargeek

comments.text:
a shelter i used to work at had taken in a cat that had killed other cats 
so I don't see why not
comments.author: datplaylist10

comments.text: Bullshit.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

comments.text:
It is one of those dirty secrets that people are ashamed to admit, but it 
absolutely happens.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
I have never seen myself or heard of such a thing as an adult cat killing a 
kitten.  Total nonsense.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

comments.text:
If your 2 year old cat has never lived with another cat, then you are 
better off getting a young (1 year to 7 years) adult cat RATHER than a 
kitten.   A young adult can defend itself if yours decides to repel it 
rather than accept it.  A kitten is often KILLED in this situation, because 
it is too young to defend itself.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
The whole point in getting a kitten is so that the kitten can LEARN how to 
socialize. Fights are less-likely to occur. However, there is nothing wrong 
with getting an adult, older, younger, or same age! Getting a kitten will 
NOT stimulate "motherly instincts". It would be a good idea to get a feline 
of the opposite gender; results tend to be better. I hope you find the 
perfect new addition to your family!
comments.author: datplaylist10

comments.text:
+Margaret Schill thanks for that ... Guess I will figure out how my cat 
reacts when I will find her a friend!
comments.author: Photoandcargeek

comments.text:
None of my adult female cats ever had any motherly instincts for stranger 
kittens.  In fact, my adult females took a lot longer to accept kittens 
than my adult males took.  In my experience, an adult female cat seems to 
do better with a cat over the wild and crazy wanting to play fight and back 
jump stage of  kittenhood.  For a 2 1/2 year old female, I think it might 
be best to get a cat close to the same age.  Regarding whether a male or 
female new cat to pair with the resident female, the sex of the new cat 
isn't as important as the temperament.  For an adult cat that never lived 
with another cat, a laid back new cat would probably be best.  Follow 
Jackson's introduction advice!  Do NOT rush anything or it won't wind up 
well.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
Kittens tend to be seen by resident cats as less of a threat starting out, 
but their high energy and bad manners can be annoying to the older cat 
(think, little sister or brother).  An adult cat is scarier at first.  Try 
and match the energy levels you think the adult cat will have for best 
results.  But a cat just 2 years older isn't going to be too stressed out 
by the workout a kitten might give,   I don't think the boy/girl difference 
is that significant if you neuter the cats.  Girls are a bit more turf 
conscious, boys a bit more active and outgoing.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

comments.text:
my cat pirate is the bomb <3 he was a rescue as a baby and is also a cancer 
survivor! he's a sweet mommies boy <3
comments.author: Chelsea Merritt

comments.text: +Chelsea Merritt sounds really cute!
comments.author: Photoandcargeek

comments.text:
as said depends on the cat, I have a male cat who is 4 now and he LOVES 
kittens and actually any cat, I cat sit for friends and sometimes they are 
in my house and he loves it and he's great about giving them space while 
they adjust, for kittens he tries to nurse them. he's an oddball though and 
loves being social

comments.text:

cats! She is an indoor cat and used to hiss at the neighbours cat when she 
could see him walking on the roof in front of our window and now they look 
at each other and almost bump noses through the little opening between the 
window and the frame ... A true Romeo and Juliet story ;)

comments.text:
It depends on your cat... I know very vague but true. I did read, however;

because they'll have the same maturity or whatever... For instance, a 
kitten wants to play and play but an older cat doesn't, usually. Though, I 
got a kitten from the shelter because my oldest took one look at my mothers

and the little one will chase each other but if I scold her she will slap

comments.text:
GET A CAT!!!!!! They are a wonderful addition to your family and will steal

work those can be worked out. I can't imagine living without Duke and Mina. 
When I feel bad, they are there to pick me up. I have Lupus and on bad days

comments.author: Cindy Bird

top_comment.text:
I have two kittens and they eat a lot and I can't tell when they are hungry 
so I just free feed them, but they are kittens. How can I tell when they 
are hungry?﻿
top_comment.author: SeSe EpicX

comments.text:
+TemeryN I agree. All you have to do is do timed feedings. Use measurements 
from the bag or from what your vet recommends. I do twice daily, once at 
9am and once at 7pm. Some people like to do smaller meals 3 times a day. 
Depends on your schedule and your cats. But believe me, they WILL start to 
know when feeding time is. And they WILL tell you. Hahah Even if I'm "late" 
 like 10 minutes, they let me know.
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
Thank you so much for the chuckle this morning =) this really brightened up 
my day - try this little experiment - don't feed them UNITL they let you 
know they are hungry, believe me, you'll know exactly when that is  =)  
(they will meow at your feet and follow you from room to room until you 
feed them, they will also try to lead you to the place where you feed them 
while they are meowing at your feet and following you around)
comments.author: TemeryN

top_comment.text:
Hey Jackson! Do you have any tips for traveling on the road with a cat? If 
anyone else has good tips for traveling, reply!

Thanks,
        -Epic ﻿
top_comment.author: EpicNickbad

comments.text: Very good advice. Thank you!
comments.author: EpicNickbad

comments.text:
Never let the cat roam around the car out of the carrier while driving.  It 
is dangerous for all because sometimes a cat will go on or under the gas or 
break pedals, or jump on the dashboard in front of the driver.  Withhold 
food for at least 3 or four hours before setting out because cats can get 
car sick if they have a full stomach.  Line the carrier with some towels, 
and a wee wee puppy training pad to absorb any eliminations.  For long 
distance travel, a large carrier with room for a litter box is good.  For a 
long distance trip, a hard carrier is best in case there is a crash- the 
cat will be more protected. And, of course, NEVER leave a cat in a car in 
the heat without AC or they can die from heat.  Cars heat up very fast in 
hot weather.  Windows cracked open is not good enough.  If the humans need 
a rest stop break, best to have one human stay in the car with the cat 
while the other person tends to their needs.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
It depends on how far you are going. I have to travel a little over an hour 
to the vets office with my cats, I usually just bring one at a time. My 
oldest will meow almost constantly in her carrier but I put her up front 
with me and so she can see me. She usually settles down after 20 minutes or 
so. Just make your cat as comfortable as possible. For instance I have a 
fabric type carrier instead of those awful plastic pet carriers so it's 
nice and soft. But as far as anything longer than that you'll need to 
research it I'm sure you'd need a litter box and food and let her roam the 
car (while you're stopped of course) let her stretch her legs and what not.
comments.author: XDementedLoveX

top_comment.text:
Maybe someone in the comments can answer if Jackson can't respond to my 
question.
My husband and I adopted two cats back in Nov 2013. One was 7 months old at 
the time, now she's a little more than a year. The other was around 1 1/2- 
2 years old. So the kitten, she was easy to teach her out of bad habits, 
get her to take treats, eat wet food, etc etc.
Our other cat.. not so much. She has a problem with scratching everything 
BUT the scratching posts we've bought and I've tried everything I can think 
of to fix it.
Also, the other thing with her that concerns me is that she will only eat 
dry cat food. We had no idea she had a distaste for wet food until we 
decided to switch up their food and treat them with some wet food... which 
we thought they'd go crazy over. The kitten did, but our other cat did not. 
In fact, she backs away from it like she is fearful. She is fine with dry 
treats, but nothing wet or that's not a dry kibble. We recently bought cat 
milk because our youngest cat goes nuts every time we have cereal. We could 
tell she really wanted to drink the milk but of course we didn't let her. 
Well, SHE LOVES the cat milk... we tried to give it to our oldest cat... 
she backs away from it like we're trying to poison her. Since we adopted 
her when she was already over 1 years old (closer to 2 most likely), I have 
no idea where this is coming from. Fear? Habit? Not being allowed to eat 
wet things? Idk...
She eats and she's healthy, I just worry she's not getting enough variety. 
Plus I want to treat her with yummy wet food or something every now and 
then! Any advice? Sorry this was long-winded.﻿
top_comment.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
Thanks everyone for suggestions. Just to update everyone: We tried cat milk 
as a treat and found out she would drink it from a flat lid. Then we tried 
wet food the same way a voila! She eats wet food now no problem (from her 
normal food dish). :)
Both cats still prefer a dry food meal but we get in wet food as often as 
we can too.

Also, dry food only causes obesity because people free feed their cats. My 
cats get a meal twice daily. 9am and 7pm. After their bowl is empty, that's 
it until the next meal. And urinary tract infections can happen because dry 
food doesn't contain water like a wet food does. Which is why you should 
monitor how much they're drinking from their water bowl. They drink a good 
amount of water every day. :)
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
+Leah Wall   Dry food does NOTHING for feline teeth because cats swallow 
most kibble like pills.  Ever see a cat yak?  The kibble looks untouched.   
That said, cats only recognize what is edible based on what their mom ate, 
so the poor deprived cat from a cereal-only household does not know the 
good stuff is edible.   It is worth encouraging her to sample wet food -- 
as dry food is known to cause obesity and urinary tract problems.    To do 
this, split the wet food eater's meal into two dishes and put one near the 
dry cruncher at mealtime, before giving her the dry stuff.   You can try 
putting a few kibbles on top of the wet food.  Over time, she might realize 
that the wet food is not hurting the other kitty and will try it.  But, NOT 
if you leave dry food out all the time.  You have to give her just a small 
amount of dry food at each meal.   Start with half the recommended amount 
based on the package directions and her weight (this is usually around a 
quarter cup), and then subtract a teaspoon until she is anxious for the 
next meal.   By feeding her just enough, she will be more tempted to try 
the wet food.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

comments.text:
Some cats just won't eat wet food. I had a cat who refused all wet food and 
treats. It's really not a big deal as long as the older cat is drinking 
plenty of water. My cat Duke has to drink right on the side of the bowl, no 
where else. He sees just fine, he is just picky about where he drinks.You 
might have a situation where the wet food looks like refuse to her because 
someone left a bowl of wet food down until it went bad so now she won't 
touch it. Keep plenty of water out and everything should be ok. Also rub 
cat nip over the scratching posts. It will draw her there instead of your 
sofa. My cat ruined 2 sofas before I found that trick, lol.
comments.author: Cindy Bird

comments.text:
It sounds like your cat has a vision problem. A couple of my cats need to 
splash the water before they drink. One of them has to have stuff put on 
his right side or he'll spin around until he finds it.
comments.author: laurapsyched

comments.text:
Exactly, +Rob Whitney . Eating meat is natural for cats... not dry kibbles. 
We actually had a "breakthrough" today! We were giving our youngest cat 
some of her cat milk and there was a drop on the table. Our other cat 
sniffed it and licked it up!!! So I thought maybe she'd lick it off a plate 
too so I gave her some and voila! She devoured it! :D Tomorrow I'm going to 
try some wet food on a plate (The "bowls" we put their dry food in aren't 
deep, they're shallow bowls, so idk if it'll be that different but we'll 
see!!).
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
+HummingHummingbird Dry food as a teeth cleaner is a RIDICULOUS myth 
perpetuated by the food manufacturers, as cats are obligate carnivores by 
design. Do you see cats in the wild looking for grains & hard food? NO! 
They get the majority of their water intake from wet food, even if you have 
water out in bowls. Dry food can cause horrible urinary blockages, 
primarily in males, can lead to horrible pain & surgery or death if not 
corrected.

Google "obligate carnivores" and the top results will say the same thing, 
and more. Raw diet is ideal, but can be difficult and expensive. Do what 
you like, but please don't make dietary suggestions without at least a 
disclaimer about being based on rumors.
comments.author: Rob Whitney (The Slapster)

comments.text:
+Leah Wall That's not true, dry food is better then wet food. Both wet and 
dry food have the same amount of vitamines,energy and etc it gives the cat. 
But dry food is better for the teeth. You'll see with dry food that they'll 
get less plaque because the dry food being hard, it scrapes away big part 
of the plaque while eating, on the other hand, wet food keeps sticking to 
the teeth, giving a lot more plaque and in the end if you wouldn't take 
care of it rotten teeth. If your cat doesn't want wet food don't try to 
give it either, dry food is as good, even better in the aspect of the teeth.
comments.author: HummingHummingbird

comments.text:
Well, I do keep them on routine and treats stay treats. I just notice with 
my cats that they like their food changed up every once in awhile and I 
know wet food is good for giving them liquids. They do drink enough, but 
it's still better IMO than dry food.
Anyways, I guess I'll just be patient.
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
We humans love variety and a nice change now and then -- but cats aren't 
like that.  They prefer the reliable routine they can count on.  I would 
settle on one or two kinds of food you want them to have and provide them, 
either together or separately, at predictable times.  Treats should remain 
treats only, an occasional special surprise -- if they become part of the 
expected mealtime ritual, you risk overfeeding and ending up with a 
heavy-set cat!  :-)
comments.author: Carol Kerns

comments.text:
I'm not a vet, however; I have two cats and they both eat dry food 
regularly I don't treat them to wet food. I do buy treats though, the ones 
that are good for their teeth and my oldest loves them but my youngest will 
not touch any treats. Basically it's going to be trial and error, I buy 
different treats when I can and see if she'll eat those, maybe it's the 
smell? I have no idea, she was never abused or anything we got her as a 
baby. As long as she's healthy I'd just say leave her be, I know you want 
to treat her lol but if she doesn't want it she doesn't want it. But as I 
said before maybe trying different brands of wet food then different 
flavors? Of course that is my opinion, perhaps next vet visit you can ask 
them?
comments.author: XDementedLoveX

top_comment.text:
My cats have been living together for about 2 years but I feed them in 
separate rooms because my male cat is a very fast eater and when he's done 
he steals the female's food. She's a Ragdoll and she's too accommodating so 
she just lets him steal it. I would like to feed them together. Any advice?﻿
top_comment.author: ramonypony

comments.text:
My boy used to do the same...to the point that he was eating soo fast it 
would upset his stomache and he would puke it all out later.

I've tried feeding him slowly spoon by spoon.
In the end i just made sure there was more then enough dinner so he learned 
that there's always enough food that he doesn't need to worry that there 
won't be enough.
comments.author: Inge VS

comments.text:
+ramonypony I have a similar problem. We adopted two females in November 
and our youngest (just over a year) eats her food PLUS tries to sneak our 
other cats food. The youngest eats fast but our older cat (2 years old) is 
a slow eater and barely finishes her meal before the next. Still trying to 
figure it out... hahaha
comments.author: Leah Wall

comments.text:
There is no problem with the cats eating in separate rooms.  One of my cats 
won't eat in the same room as my other cats.  It is better for all 
creatures to be able eat without worry that their food will be "stolen" by 
another.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
+Linda Foley Well, neither of them are allowed on the counter and it 
wouldn't matter how high or low I put it he would jump up or down to get to 
her food, if he can reach it he will eat it. If I put her food down first 
he would just eat hers. She finishes eating a few minutes after him and 
then I open the door. There's a second door to the room where she eats and 
if I forget to close that door sometimes he'll go around through the door 
and get her food. He was a stray in the city when I found him, had to 
scrounge for food, so he'll eat any food he can get to. Thanks for trying 
to help.
comments.author: ramonypony

comments.text:
I had a cat like that. I fed them on different levels, one on counter and 
the other on floor. The fast eater;s bowl was put down second giving the 
other a chance to eat, Plus I gave treats when necessary (just dry cat 
foot).
comments.author: Linda Foley

top_comment.text:
Repost from the instagram account:

" Hello friends and @thecatdaddy. http://instagram.com/p/rA_o6jrx5P/ 
They're my feline family the calico is Maggie she's six. The white and 
black is Maya she's almost 3. Muriel the black one and our little Sam. 
They're all rescued from the streets. They live also with 2 rescued 
poodles. They all get along. Except Maya she doesn't trust the others and 
her insecurity is causing the others to attack her :(... advices? Meal time 
is not a problem as you noticed﻿
top_comment.author: Azaria Abarca

comments.text:
I would take Maya to the vet for a full check up.  Often, when one animal 
has a health issue the others will stalk and sometimes attack.

If no health issues, do a reintroduction following the techniques in 
Jackson's video.  It is possible that the integration of Maya was done too 
quickly for her.  If all that does not help, I would have her in another 
room shut off from the other cats when you are sleeping or not home, so she 
can have lots of peaceful, stress free time.  You might also try to find 
her a new home as an only cat, or in a home with just one other cat that 
has a mellow temperament, and where you instruct the new  owners on doing a 
very slow introduction.

In addition, when you feed them, don't have them all bunched up together.  
That leads to many cats eating too quickly for fear the others will nudge 
in to get the other's food. Eating too fast can wind up causing stomach 
upset and regurgitation/vomiting.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

comments.text:
You can give everyone a dose of Rescue Remedy (up to 5 drops per day per 
cat or kitten) to take the edge off.  It will make Maya less fearful and 
the others less aggressive.  Watch for any aggression aimed toward Maya - 
heavy staring, stalking, growling, hissing, or chasing -- and give the 
aggressor a 10 minute timeout in  a carrier or the bathroom.  Then be sure 
to redirect aggression toward toys to play-out those predatorial energies 
before Maya can be victimized again.  Kitty fishing poles or laser mice 
generally work best as prey substitutes.
comments.author: Nyc Siamese

top_comment.text:
I need your help. I recently moved to a new house. My cat got used to it 
and everything was fine, but there was already another cat living here. She 
acts super aggressively to him. I though it was the age difference, since 
she's 3 years old, and the other guy is 12. But they lived together for a 
few years before, then got separated for about 2 years. The male cat is 
calm and friendly, while the female is just so aggressive. I tried 
everything in your video, but she just won't change. I've been doing it for 
weeks too. I'm not sure what to do. Please help.﻿
top_comment.author: CelestialGaming

comments.text: +Fair Horsemanship yeah, i'm glad everything worked out :)
comments.author: CelestialGaming

comments.text: That's great news :)
comments.author: Fair Horsemanship

comments.text:
+Fair Horsemanship Thank you for your help. But everything's fine now. She 
just suddenly decided to be nice and isn't aggressive anymore. I really 
appreciate your help though :)
comments.author: CelestialGaming

comments.text:
Aggression can have physiological, hormonal causes. I would recommend to 
take her to the vet to rules this out. Also it would be useful to know what 
happened during these 2years of separation.
comments.author: Fair Horsemanship

top_comment.text:
+Jackson Galaxy can you please please talk about when cats get along the 
good the bad and the ugly.. should I let them use each others litter boxes? 
... I have a 2 month old calico mix kitten I got for my 9 month old gray 
tabby mix everything is going great they play with each they sleep w each 
other but I can't seem to keep them in there own litter boxes... Help me 
understand them please ﻿
top_comment.author: Breeanna Valadez

comments.text:
As long as you keep the boxes clean, it doesn't matter. My cats share each 
other's litter boxes with no problem. It's just a sign they accept each 
other in "their" territory.
comments.author: Cindy Bird

comments.text:
Thank you guys for the help I understand 
I really am grateful that both like each other happy cats happy home :)
comments.author: Breeanna Valadez

comments.text:
that's pretty similar to my girls... One of my cats is slightly ocd and 
only does #1 on one end of the box and #2 on the other end... Kinda weird, 
but whatever. Cat. Lol The kitten, on the other hand just kinda does both 
in both boxes, wherever she feels like it.
comments.author: soccer69heit

comments.text: there's nothing wrong with them sharing boxes.. Nothing to worry about. (:
comments.author: soccer69heit

comments.text:
it's ok if they share litter boxes, I once had 9 cats sharing 5 litter 
boxes (that was NOT fun!). You'll most likely find that they mostly do 
#1 in one box and mostly #2 in the other (some mix will happen tho), at 
least that's the way it is for my 2 girls (down to only 2 cats and 2 litter 
boxes, YAH!).
comments.author: TemeryN

top_comment.text:
I have 2 brother's that used to get along...and now when they get in range 
of each-other it's a count down until WW3 erupts.  I wonder if this will 
work for them too.﻿
top_comment.author: Libby F

comments.text:
Thank  you very much for your advice!  We're putting it all into play now. 
 Crossing fingers. :)
comments.author: Libby F

comments.text:
A slow re-introduction is a way to try to get peace back between two cats.  
So give it a try. Just be sure to go slowly, and end each session when 
things are going WELL, not waiting for a problem before separating them.  
To start, they must be kept separate all the time until you are managing a 
very short session of seeing each other.  You want them to only experience 
good things in the presence of the other, so that over many weeks they 
might forget about being enemies and go back to getting along. Pay very 
close attention to their body language to see any signs of starting to get 
upset, and separate them at that time.
comments.author: Margaret Schill

captions.text: Hey there people.

Today we can do the quest to
answer all the supermarket
questions.
Stand by.
First things first.
Catify ze world!

I get asked the same questions
usually at the supermarket.

So today we're going to
knock out the first one.

Jackson, I'm trying to
introduce one cat to another,
and it ain't going well.

Today we're talking
about introductions.

Now let's get down
to the brass tacks.
How do we introduce cat to cat?

The first thing that folks
do wrong, is they go well,

I'm just going to bring my cat
into a room with this new cat
and let them work it out.

How many times have I
heard, let them work it out?

And how many times do
they not work it out?

What you want to do is introduce
these guys by scent first
and then work in sight.
It's all about cat mojo folks.

It's about
territorial ownership.

And if your cat, who has owned
this territory for x amount

of time, suddenly doesn't,
we're getting them off

on the wrong foot, because
you're putting it squarely
in the land of threat.

This cat is threatening
your cat's sanctified space.

The way that I introduce
cat to cat is I use a door.

I want to make sure that
on one side of the door,
it's usually a good base camp.

Base camp is a
room that's almost

like territorial
training wheels.
Right?

Well, first I'm going
to give you this room.

So you get to know what
the territory smells like.

And then we'll graduate
you out of here.

And I want you to
make sure that you're
practicing site swapping.

So what you want to
do, for instance,

is you've got the cat that's
out in the rest of the house.
Well, it's time to switch.
Put this one in the bathroom.
Bring the other one out.

Take the one from the
bathroom into the other room.

Now this whole thing will
take 3 and 1/2 minutes,

but I do want to make sure
that at any given time

the new cat or the resident cat
has a place to call their own.

Both a little bit
away and base camp.

The seat of the territory,
and the whole rest
of the territory.

On the other side
of that door, you

have your resident cat,
who has, for the most part,
free run of the house.

And you're going to
introduce them at meal times.

One on one side of the
door, one on the other.

If you are feeding
meals, you're gold, man.

Because your cat's
hungry, they're

going to want to
eat at that door.

they're motivated
to eat at that door.

And so they're going to
overcome the misgiving

they might have
with that other cat.

So that's really,
really crucial that you

keep feeding meals
and not free feeding.

Give them about three feet
on either side of that door.
Three feet from bowl to door.

Another three feet
from bowl to door.
Six feet total.

That way we're pretty
much respecting

the concept of personal space,
and a little bit of privacy.
And what are we doing?

We're setting up the concept
of positive association.
Right?

So that when these cats smell
food, they smell one another.
Now here's what I want from you.

When the two cats are eating
on either side of the door,
I want to see nothing.
No hissing.
No growling.
No shenanigans under the door.
No nothing.
OK.

Well if that's not happening,
then bring the bowls
apart a little bit more.

So what we're doing now,
as we've done in the past,
is setting a challenge line.

Saying you know,
where is it, Mr.

Cat that you find
enough confidence

that you can walk up to that
bowl, smell the other cat,

but smell your food,
eat it and walk away.

Wherever that is, that's
where we put a piece of tape

on the ground on either
side of that door.
Boom.

We got challenge
lines on either side,

and that first couple of
nights, walk up to the bowl,
eat, walk away, and onward.

Obviously, the next
thing you're going to do

is you're going to start moving
those bowls closer and closer
together.
We do this slowly.

Remember, a cat needs
to have it proven

to them that's this other
being is not a threat to them.

And the only way we can do
that is having the same result
over and over and over again.

Every time a bowl goes
down, I get my jackpot food.

I get no threat to the
environment, whatsoever.
I walk away.
You know, it's all good.

Another part of this
homework is graduate
from a closed door to the gate.

With the gate, you drape a
towel over the gate itself.

So now you've got a little bit
of visual space at the bottom.

So now these guys can
be eating their dinner

at their respective
challenge lines,

looking under there going,
wait a second, that's

a [NOM NOM NOM] that's
another [NOM NOM NOM].

It's like, I really want to
pay attention to that thing,
but it's really small, visually.
And this is really good food.

Now the next step is an exercise
that I call, Eat, Play, Love.

And the idea was you take two
cats that stand one another,

you put them in the same room,
but completely supervised.

And the idea is you want to
give them experience with toys.
What are their favorite toys?

How do you keep them
interacting with you,

and not paying any attention
to the other cat in the room?

Through play, then
through feeding a meal,

then through just
loving on them.

I just want them to
ignore one another.
That's the object of the game.

If it lasts for 15 seconds
before one cat's like,
huh, hey what the?
Who's that?

And then, all of
a sudden, game on.
Well that's fine.
That was 15 seconds.

Always end exercises
on a high note

to the best of your
ability, because we

don't want negative
associations to take root.

Every time these guys
get in a room together,
I want good things to happen.
They want good things to happen.

And if they do
continue to happen,

we will get to that point where
we'll be able to open the door
and let them at each other.

Everything that I just told you
about introducing cat to cat

works just as well when
your cats have had a fight,

and you're trying to get
them back together again.

So your homework for introducing
cat to cat, number 1,
start feeding meals only.
No free feeding.

Second, meal time
goes on opposite sides
of a closed door.

Every time you get
positive results,

stay with it for
a few days, folks.
Don't rush it.

It's on cat time,
not human time.

Then we get to the point
where we're right at the door.

A couple things you can
do, back it up again.

And now you can use the
baby gate type of deal.
Right?

You put the baby gate
down, put a blanket on top.

Slowly raising the curtain
on the proceedings,
and also bringing them together.

Again, repeating the same
technique you used before.

The other part of your
homework is Eat, Play, Love.

Concept here is expanding
out that meal time ritual.
Make sure you're site swapping.
Very, very important.

I don't want anyone
to get sort of static
in one location in the house.

I want it to be a
mix of locations

so that nobody can settle
into sort of false ownership.
And that's it.
Finally guys.

I'm telling you this from
the bottom of my heart.

I think cats should
be living groups.

I think that you should have
more than one cat in your life,
for sure.

But you've got to introduce
them on their terms.

All right folks, I'm
going to get going.

Now I have answered the
supermarket question
of the day.
More to come, believe me.

In the meantime, you can ask
your supermarket question.

You do not have to wait until
I'm holding a bag a celery
online at the Whole Foods.
No.

What you can do is #
TeamCatMojo, right here,
you see that.

And send it off on Twitter,
on Instagram, on Facebook.

And I will see those
questions and if I

get asked them enough
times, I will, for sure
answer those questions.

All right folks, until
next time, all light,
all love, all mojo to ya.

[KISSES] Love to you,
and your multiple cats.

title: The Best Way To Introduce Your Two Cats
